article.title: On the connectedness of the set of Riemann surfaces with real moduli

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of transformations are represented by the elements *x<sub>i</sub>* in the fundamental domain for K?
How is the fundamental domain for Δ constructed in relation to the fundamental domain for K?
choices: It is identical to the fundamental domain for K.
It is a subset of the fundamental domain for K.
It is the union of the fundamental domain for K and its image under the reflection τ<sub>1</sub>.
It is the complement of the fundamental domain for K within the unit disc.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the homomorphism η represent in the context of the paper?
choices: An isomorphism between Δ and a Fuchsian group.
A mapping from Δ to a cyclic group of order 2.
A surjective homomorphism from Δ to a cyclic group of order 2n, with kernel being a Fuchsian group uniformizing a closed Riemann surface S.
An injective homomorphism from Δ to the group of all Möbius transformations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of Lemma 1 in proving the main theorem of the paper?
choices: It demonstrates that every abelian group can be realized as a subgroup of an NEC group.
It establishes that the kernel of a specific homomorphism is a normal subgroup of the NEC group K, which is crucial for proving that the set of Riemann surfaces with real moduli is connected.
It provides a method for constructing new Riemann surfaces with specific properties.
It proves that the quotient of an NEC group by a normal subgroup is always a Fuchsian group.
